content:
@loogle GradedAlgebra
docs#GradedAlgebra
:search: docs#ProjectiveSpectrum, docs#AlgebraicGeometry.germ_comp_stalkToFiberRingHom, and 183 more
Public service announcement: this topic may be used for chatting with loogle. Everyone is welcome to use it, but many people may also want to mute the topic!
So the idea is that you are encouraging us to send our queries to this thread rather than PMing the bot directly?
Only slightly seriously. I thought it would be amusing to watching people using loogle. But it might also be noisy and distracting. :-)
@loogle pwFilter
I think we will see some uses of the bot in response to questions all over
Should the loogle above @loogle GradedAlgebrafind docs#GradedAlgebra ? Did it?
@loogle pwFilter
:exclamation: unknown identifier 'pwFilter'
that could use some work, autocomplete can do better than that
@loogle "pwFilter"
I think that loogle does not pick up on edits.
(on Zulip editing a post to ping someone doesn't work BTW, or at least it didn't used to work)
@loogle "pwFilter"
:exclamation: Cannot search: No constants in search pattern.
If I knew what the constant was named I wouldn't be asking you :expressionless:
I do not think that @loogle GradedAlgebra returned docs#GradedAlgebra as an answer.
I think that's because GradedAlgebra doesn't have a type that mentions GradedAlgebra

Ah, so
@loogle "GradedAlgebra"
should work?
@loogle "GradedAlgebra"
:exclamation: Cannot search: No constants in search pattern.
Oh, you already fell in this trap
I guess this is a bit of mismatch between what one expects from a "search engine" vs something that searches for a constant by type
Yes, ok, I need to adapt my expectation of what I should find and what not.
or it needs to expand in scope
@loogle (List.join (List.map (fun z => ?a ++ z) ?b))
:search: docs#List.append_join_map_append
While it's probably reasonable to expand the scope to include constants, it is probably also better to leave this for a subsequent PR
@loogle (List.join (List.map (?a ++ ¬∑) ?b))
@loogle (List.join (List.map (?a ++ ¬∑) ?b))
:search: docs#List.append_join_map_append
@loogle String ‚Üí Nat ‚Üí Char ‚Üí String
:exclamation: <input>:1:7: expected end of input
@loogle (String ‚Üí Nat ‚Üí Char ‚Üí String)
@loogle (String ‚Üí Nat ‚Üí Char ‚Üí String)
:shrug: nothing found
Am I doing that wrong? I wanted String.leftpad.
@loogle (Nat ‚Üí Char ‚Üí String ‚Üí String)
:search: docs#String.leftpad
Oh, I thought I read in the docs that the argument order wasn't important.
@loogle String Nat Char |- String
:search: docs#String.leftpad, docs#String.pushn, and 1 more
Got it.

@loogle |- (String -> Nat -> Char -> String)
Should hopefully work
:search: docs#String.leftpad, docs#String.pushn
the "and 1 more" returned from my query and not yours is def String.replicate (n : Nat) (c : Char) : String, it is surprising that my query would match this
Zulip lost a message here :-(

Your original query was a subexpression query, with no special handling of promises.
Your second query filtered by 3 constants, no matter where they are, and the last filter required the conclusion to be String.
My query was a conclusion pattern, where premises are possibly reordered.
The next deployment will require commas between multiple conditions, that will make things clearer.

Good to see where the UX is suboptimal here!
oh, a b |- c reads like a hypothesis/goal pattern

Yes, I understand the confusion. That query will be
a, b, |- c after the next deployment, which will hopefully be less misleading
@loogle ((Fin (_ + _) -> Sum (Fin _) (Fin _))
:exclamation: <input>:1:37: unexpected end of input; expected ')', ',' or ':'
@loogle (Fin (_ + _) -> Sum (Fin _) (Fin _))
:shrug: nothing found
@loogle (Equiv (Fin (_ + _)) (Sum (Fin _) (Fin _)))
:search: finSumFinEquiv_symm_apply_castAdd, finSumFinEquiv_symm_apply_natAdd, and 1 more

This helped me find the thing docs#finSumFinEquiv I was looking for, but I have no idea why it's giving me these responses rather than finSumFinEquiv itself. These things don't seem to reference Equiv itself directly.
I guess they reference it in some implicit type argument, e.g. the coercion. So that's not completely unexpected. I wonder why the definition itself wasn't listed.
Why is finSumFinEquiv not a link in the lemma statements on the docs page?
@loogle (Equiv (Sum (Fin _) (Fin _)) (Fin (_ + _)))
:search: finSumFinEquiv, finSumFinEquiv_apply_left, and 1 more
Ah, of course!

@loogle Fin ( _ + _), Sum (Fin _) (Fin _)
is how I think I'd have approached this search problem: this way the order doesn't matter, and also whether it's an equiv or maybe something similar
(but hindsight is something something)
:search: finSumFinEquiv, finSumFinEquiv_apply_left, and 4 more
@loogle List.indexesOf
:shrug: nothing found
@loogle RingHom.id (ZMod _)
:search: ZMod.frobenius_zmod, GaloisField.splits_zmod_X_pow_sub_X, and 1 more
the 1 more is docs#FiniteField.trace_to_zmod_nondegenerate - I don't get why this shows up.

Strange indeed. Maybe isDefEq reduces RingHom.id to identity during pattern matching? But I don't get why this lemma is even considered, i.e. why it appears in the index under ‚Äúmentions RingHom.id‚Äù ü§∑‚Äç‚ôÇÔ∏è
@loogle Multiset.map Finset.univ

:exclamation:

application type mismatch
  Multiset.map Finset.univ
argument
  Finset.univ
has type
  Finset ?m.43699575 : Type ?u.43699574
but is expected to have type
  ?m.43699572 ‚Üí ?m.43699573 : Type (max ?u.43699570 ?u.43699571)

:search: Equiv.finsuppUnique_symm_apply_support_val, MvPolynomial.aeval_esymm_eq_multiset_esymm, and 4 more
@loogle Multiset.map, Finset.univ, Function.Bijective
:shrug: nothing found
@loogle Finset.map, Finset.univ, Function.Bijective
:shrug: nothing found
https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/Data/Multiset/Fintype.html#Multiset.map_univ is not what you were looking for?

No, I want this

/-- If f is a bijection of finite sets, it maps universes into universes. -/
@[simp]
theorem map_univ_eq_univ_of_bijection (f : Œ± ‚Üí Œ≤) (hf : Function.Bijective f) :
    map f (Finset.univ : Finset Œ±).val = univ.val := by
  -- TODO: Note the converse is also true (a function mapping universes to universes is bijective)
  -- this converse should turn into a @[simp] iff lemma.
  ext a
  rw [Function.bijective_iff_has_inverse] at hf
  rcases hf with ‚ü®f_inv, hf_inv, hf_inv'‚ü©
  have ha : a = f (f_inv a) := by
    unfold Function.RightInverse Function.LeftInverse at hf_inv'
    simp [hf_inv']
  rw [count_univ, ha, count_map_eq_count']
  simp only [mem_val, mem_univ, not_true, count_univ]
  exact Function.LeftInverse.injective hf_inv
The reverse direction has turned out to be much more difficult than it feels like it should be.
Doesn't f just have to be surjective?
Oh I see why you're mixing multisets and need bijective
I thought that univ stood for "universal set" not "universe"
@loogle ((?m + ?n) + ?k = ?m + ( ?n + ?k))
Failure! Bot is unavailable
@Joachim Breitner /o\
It times out Zulip, too slow given the large number of lemma involving = and +. On the web page you should get a response, I hope.
@loogle |- ((?m + ?n) + ?k = ?m + ( ?n + ?k))
Failure! Bot is unavailable

(deterministic) timeout at 'isDefEq', maximum number of heartbeats (200000) has been reached (use 'set_option maxHeartbeats <num>' to set the limit)

not so^^
Also not if I give type hints (((?m : Nat) + (?n : Nat)) + (?k : Nat) = ?m + ( ?n + ?k))
https://loogle.lean-fro.org/?q=%7C-+%28%28%3Fm+%2B+%3Fn%29+%2B+%3Fk+%3D+%3Fm+%2B+%28+%3Fn+%2B+%3Fk%29%29 works, it seems
That's |- ((?m + ?n) + ?k = ?m + ( ?n + ?k))
What difference does |- make here?
I fear looking at all subexpressions of 10k lemmas is just going to be rather expensive
Without it it lists all lemmas that match your pattern anywhere
With it, only the conclusion is matched
(deleted)
@loogle Lean.FVarId -> Lean.MetaM Lean.Expr
:search: Lean.FVarId.getType
@Joachim Breitner, can the loogle results page show the types of the things it found? That would make it 10x more useful to me.

In principle yes. I had three dozens docs tabs open next to my Loogle tab yesterday, so I know what you mean :-)

I'm unsure about the best way to present it, as types can get large. Simply below? On hover? Collapsible? But then next you'd really want the terms there to be hoverable/clickable as well, and the little POC page suddenly gets quite out of hand, and starts duplicating logic from the docs page‚Ä¶

Is your use case using Loogle while proving things? Then it may be better UX to enable the use of Loogle inside VS Code, to avoid the tool switch. The low tech solution is to use #find in a tab with import Mathlib. The next level would be integration into the VS Code plugin; I imagine a ‚Äúloogle pane‚Äù that you can open (like the info view or the error list) with a search field. Then all your usual VS Code niceties (jump to definition, hover to explore the types, maybe even a hotkey to insert the result into your current document) will apply. Maybe it could even somehow take the current context (opened namespaces) into account so that you don't have to enter queries fully qualified!

Is anyone edited about that prospect and likes to work on IDE integration? Happy to assist!
I mean, do we even need to run #find in tab with import Mathlib? If everything is in a global precomputed cache, you could run it from anywhere.
(Maybe then it can't show the types for the unimported stuff?)
Yes, that is my worry; it may not even be able to search the types for the unimported stuff‚Ä¶
I wonder if I can use the doc site generation code as a library, and not only render the type nicely, but also the docstring, and render it all in the same style as in the docs, that might be pretty

:shrug: nothing found

Come on lol
@loogle MvPolynomial.support, "nonempty"
:shrug: nothing found
Are we looking for the same thing, I guess @Eric Rodriguez ?
I was trying to see if it was there with docs#Set.Nonempty or docs#Finset.Nonempty

Well, I was surprised not to see it. It's in my S-Z PR

@[simp]
lemma MvPolynomial.support_nonempty_iff {F œÉ} [CommSemiring F] (p : MvPolynomial œÉ F) :
    (MvPolynomial.support p).Nonempty ‚Üî p ‚â† 0 := by
  rw [ne_eq, ‚ÜêMvPolynomial.support_eq_empty, Finset.nonempty_iff_ne_empty]
Not sure if I've spun it out yet somewhere I was going to use it in #7206, but just inlined it.
There should be the same thing for Polynomial.

I think that around Polynomials, ne_empty is more common:

import Mathlib.Data.MvPolynomial.Basic
import Mathlib.Data.Polynomial.Basic

example {R} [Semiring R] {f : Polynomial R} : f.support.Nonempty ‚Üî f ‚â† 0 :=
Finset.nonempty_iff_ne_empty.trans Polynomial.support_eq_empty.not

example {F œÉ} [CommSemiring F] (p : MvPolynomial œÉ F) :
    (MvPolynomial.support p).Nonempty ‚Üî p ‚â† 0 :=
Finset.nonempty_iff_ne_empty.trans MvPolynomial.support_eq_empty.not
Loogle may be lagging behind master; the updating isn't automated yet

(deleted)
Are you looking for Int.cast?
@loogle Int |- Fin ?n
:exclamation: <input>:1:4: expected end of input

Ya√´l Dillies said:

Are you looking for Int.cast?

Yes! I was surprised when it didn't coerce by adding a type annotation, and wasn't sure where it was...
But also, I wonder why that loogle query didn't work...
@loogle Int |- Fin _
:exclamation: <input>:1:4: expected end of input
Wait, it doesn't like |- for some reason...
Let's try one that worked earlier:
@loogle String Nat Char |- String
:exclamation: <input>:1:16: expected end of input
With updated syntax, maybe?
@loogle String, Nat, Char |- String
:exclamation: <input>:1:18: expected end of input
Wait a minute...does it insist on a trailing comma after the hypotheses?
@loogle String, Nat, Char, |- String
:search: String.pushn, String.leftpad, and 1 more
Oh, wait, hypotheses have to be specified after the |- by arrow notation, I see! The non-turnstile comma separated terms are just searching anywhere in the expression.
@loogle |- Int -> Fin _
:shrug: nothing found
@loogle |- IntCast (Fin _)
:shrug: nothing found
Int has a coercion to Fin n only if n ‚â† 0, so you need to specify that somehow. The instance is docs#Fin.instAddMonoidWithOne, so the way to specify that is a NeZero n assumption.

Ah, thank you!! (Original loogle!! :) ) Hmmm‚Äîultimately I want a Nat. Do you happen to know if there's a modulo operation on Ints, by Nats, which goes directly to Nats? I guess you still want the argument Nat to not be zero to actually make sense most of the time, but I can live with a junk value more easily in this situation...

Hang on, we'd want -4 % 0 to be -4, mathematically (just not "in practice" in the case I'm using this in (array indexing)), so I guess we can't land in Nat in general even when modding by a Nat...maybe making Fin work will be fine.
docs#Int.natMod
(I'm glad Loogle hasn't fully replaced me quite yet :stuck_out_tongue_closed_eyes:)
Great, that worked, thanks! :D Now I can index into arrays with Ints :)
There's also docs#Int.natAbs

Oh, wait, hypotheses have to be specified after the |- by arrow notation, I see! The non-turnstile comma separated terms are just searching anywhere in the expression.

Yes, the turnstyle is a little maker in front of the whole type (with assumptions) to match against, and the commas separate independent queries/filters. Maybe the symbol is too confusing here. But what would work better? An explicit not-in-subterm: is a bit noisy.

Yeah, I‚Äôm not really sure what would be better‚Äîfitting a complex query into a single line of syntax is a difficult issue! Here are a couple ideas, though each has their tradeoffs:

  1. Use spaces for separating hypotheses, e.g. a, b, c d |-e would be the same as a, b, |- c ‚Üí d ‚Üí e is now (but this might create confusion for e.g. f a b |- c‚Äîoh, right, it has to be (f a b) |- c!)
  2. Use semicolons for separating anywhere-queries and commas for separating hypothesis queries, e.g. a; b; c, d |- e (clunky for ordinary a; b; c queries? but unambiguous‚Ä¶)
  3. Use only commas and parentheses, and try to interpret in a ‚Äúsmart‚Äù way‚Äîpossibly prone to confusion/unpredictability, but this would parse all of the following:
    ‚Ä¢ a, b, c |- d has a, b, c as hypothesis queries
    ‚Ä¢ a, b, c |- d, e has a, b, c as hypothesis queries and e as a top-level query (or maybe this is banned)
    ‚Ä¢ a, b, c, |- d, e has a, b, c, e as top-level queries (note the comma!) (or maybe this pattern is banned)
    ‚Ä¢ a, (b, c |- d), e has a, e as top level queries and b, c as hypothesis queries

Semicolons and commas would be an option. I fear it might optimize for the wrong thing ‚Äì I‚Äôd expect listing constants and name fragments to be more common than complex conclusion-only patterns (which are a rather advanced feature of sorts).

Note that @loogle a ‚Üí b ‚Üíc will always find whatever @loogle |- a ‚Üí b ‚Üí c finds, so one should only have to even think about |- when the former is too slow or has too many unwanted results. So complicated syntax rules for this extra search refinement might not pay off.

(I am not sure if this behaviour - that |- is only ever an additional restriction ‚Äì is known among looglers.)
Ah, does @loogle a ‚Üí b ‚Üí c now not care about the order of the premises?
No, not any more. It applies the same (imperfect) matching code as |- a ‚Üí b ‚Üí c, but at every subexpression of the term.

@loogle Nat ‚Üí Bool, "Prod.allI"
This finds this even thought the Nat ‚Üí Bool occurs nested in

def Prod.allI (f : Nat ‚Üí Bool) (i : Nat √ó Nat) : Bool
:search: Prod.allI

Oh, that‚Äôs great! :) I guess that makes |- mostly unnecessary‚Äîmy main motivation really was that |- a ‚Üí b ‚Üí c ‚Äúlooks a little wrong‚Äù‚Äîusually the hypotheses are to the left of the |-, so it was intuitive to think they could be put there since |- exists. Plus the appearance of them inside ‚Üí suggests that they actually can‚Äôt be reordered (a, b |- c feels more ‚Äúorder-free‚Äù to me), and we need to remember the behavior specified in the docs. But these are ultimately minor things, and it‚Äôs not too hard to learn them away. :)
(deleted ‚Äî I didn't know how to summon @loogle)
You have to mention @loogle in the Zulip sense, I get an autocompletion that adds ** around the name
:exclamation: <input>:1:4: expected end of input
Or simply use https://loogle.lean-fro.org/
I ended up sending a direct message, thank you for your help!

Is there any way to exclude the modular forms results, for example?

No, not yet at least. Prefixing queries with ! would probably work.
Which Mod do you want here? maybe searching by identifier and not by name substring works better?

@loogle Fin, ?_ % ?_

This is maybe a hack, but you can try to match on Mod in your expressions.
:search: Fin.add_def, Fin.coe_mul, and 40 more
I want the operation Nat -> Fin n that's effectively mod, but I'm realising that I should probably just use coe

Michael Stoll said:

loogle (¬¨ ?P ‚Üí ¬¨ ?Q), (?Q ‚Üí ?P)

I was wondering why exact? and apply? fail here:

import Mathlib.Tactic

example {P Q : Prop} (h : ¬¨ P ‚Üí  ¬¨ Q) : Q ‚Üí P := by exact?
-- `exact?` could not close the goal. Try `apply?` to see partial suggestions.
example {P Q : Prop} (h : ¬¨ P ‚Üí  ¬¨ Q) : Q ‚Üí P := by apply?
-- apply? didn't find any relevant lemmas

example {P Q : Prop} (h : ¬¨ P ‚Üí  ¬¨ Q) : Q ‚Üí P := h.mtr
That's probably because those are very generic goals. We avoid indexing those to pollute results.
Maybe exact?, apply? and friends could mention this in these cases?

As I think I've said somewhere earlier, with the current design of exact?is may be feasible to put back in these very generic results. We do better sorting of the candidates now, so the generic results should be tried last, and we also have an automatic "stop before you timeout" mechanism, so there is no danger of having too many lemmas.
If someone wants to try this, just find where the exact? code uses insertIfSpecific and change it to insert, then let us know how things go!

Yeah that's docs#sInf. If you want the infimum of a set s in a conditionally complete lattice alpha, either use sInf s (with junk value) or iInf fun a => iInf fun _ : a in s => (a : WithBot (WithTop alpha) (this has good notation, but I'm on my phone).

And to get a positive match:
@loogle "Rat", |- ?a ‚â§ ?b -> ?b ‚â§ ?a -> _
:search: Rat.le_antisymm

If you don't use |-, then the pattern is applied anywhere in the goal - including under lambdas. This way, for example, the _ ^ _ matches under the lambda in
@loogle tsum, _ ^ _
If you use |-, then you are matching against the top-level assumptions and conclusion of the type.
:search: tsum_geometric_inv_two, ENNReal.tsum_geometric, and 61 more
I see, sometimes it's hard to use |- because you just want an implication, but it may be stated as an Iff, or the iff may have conditions, etc

Yes, I definitely see the point. Maybe loogle should assume that if you re-use metavariable names, then you do want both to match in the same context anyways. The current implementation isn‚Äôt helpful for that (it treats each pattern very separately), and I wonder if this means backtracking if the first pattern matches in multiple locations. Not trivial.

Do you think Loogle should be looking at instance arguments? They are supposed to be canonical.

If they are, then it shouldn‚Äôt matter if we are looking at it, shouldn‚Äôt it :-)
Loogle is simply using isDefEq under the hood. It tries to not have too much smarts in it. And maybe the problem is somewhere else, didn‚Äôt look yet.

My interpretation of the output I get on loogle.lean-lang.org is that Loogle is explicitly filtering out all declarations that don't contain the instances mentioned in (the term it elaborates from) ENNReal ~=o ENNReal^od.
This seems wrong in that ENNReal ~=o ENNReal^od elaborates to different terms (with different instances mentioned) depending on which files you import

Ah, I see, that would be a problem. Is that (import-dependent elaboration) a bug in mathlib, or a feature? Are these different terms going to be defeq (i.e. would I only have to adjust the index I‚Äôm using)?

I thought that import-dependent elaboration was a consequence of how Lean works, not something that should be addressed in mathlib.

I am not sure about this, but my mental model for this is that TC does its thing in some order that is dependent on import availability and import order and that there is not much that can be done about this.
Not my area of expertise. If you have overlapping instances, then that‚Äôs certainly plausible.
There are recent and not so recent experiments showing the overall effects of simply sorting the imports.
Yeah there is really no hope of having import-independent elaboration (and we do (ab)use import-dependent elaboration in mathlib anyway)
My suggestion for Loogle is to ignore instance arguments, as they are a common source of import-dependent elaboration

Ok ‚Äì but only for the purpose of the ‚Äúwhich contants are mentioned‚Äù index, or also when pattern matching? In other words: Can I still use isDefEq, because these instances will be definitionaly equal, or do I have to reimplement that too?

Ok, in this case they are defeq, tested using

import Mathlib
open Lean Meta
run_cmd Lean.Elab.Command.runTermElabM fun _ => do
  let ci ‚Üê getConstInfo ``OrderIso.invENNReal
  let s ‚Üê `(ENNReal ‚âÉo ENNReal·µí·µà)
  let e ‚Üê Lean.Elab.Term.elabTermAndSynthesize s none
  let b ‚Üê isDefEq ci.type e
  logInfo m!"{Expr.getUsedConstants ci.type}\n vs\n{Expr.getUsedConstants e}\neq: {b}"
Issue at https://github.com/nomeata/loogle/issues/18
